Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: G-SESAME Cloud: A Dynamically Scalable Collaboration Community for Biological Knowledge Discovery
Award.AbstractNarration:
Clemson University and the University of Illinois at Chicago are awarded grants to develop a dynamically scalable collaboration community, G-SESAME Cloud, for biological knowledge discovery. The first aim of this project is to enhance the popular G-SESAME (Gene Semantic Similarity Analysis and Measurement) tools (http://bioinformatics.clemson.edu/G-SESAME) in terms of methodology, functionality, accuracy, efficiency, and scalability to address the immediate needs of researchers who utilize G-SESAME tools in their daily biological research. The ultimate goal is to build a community-based scalable cloud computing infrastructure (G-SESAME Cloud) to help the biological researchers disseminate their research results. This infrastructure will provide a set of Web-based tools for biological researchers to automatically (or semi-automatically) convert their GO-based biological programs developed in any programming languages under any platforms into Web services and publish them on the G-SESAME Cloud. Researchers can also use a configuration utility developed in this project to easily configure their computing facilities into the G-SESAME Cloud.
This project will produce a complete set of Web services for measuring the functional similarity of biological entities using different methods, and for discovering biological knowledge based on such similarity values. The G-SESAME Cloud will provide a community-based, effective and self-scalable cloud computing environment in which researchers can easily publish their biological application software as a service (SaaS) and share their computing infrastructure as a service (IaaS).
The G-SESAME Cloud and its GO-based Web services will release the burden of biological researchers from learning Web technologies and maintaining their own computing facilities so that they can focus on their research. The success of this project will set an example for building self-scalable community-based biological Cloud to promote resource sharing and SaaS, IaaS and PaaS (Platform as a Service) concepts in biological research community. This project will also be used to train Computer Science students, including women and minority students, on distributed computing, data mining, and Web technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we investigated various ways to improve the performance of G-SESAME web services. We designed new algorithms to measure the semantic similarity of biological ontology terms, and thus measure the functional similarity of biological entities. We parallelized the G-SESAME algorithms with Clemson’s Palmetto Cluster System and studied how to exploit idle computing resources in instruction and research labs to implement the performance of G-SESAME web services. We developed an ontology graph based algorithm to efficiently retrieve biological articles from the MEDLINE database and then designed new algorithms to measure the semantic similarity of GO terms based on their co-occurrences in biomedical articles. We tried to address the fault tolerance problems of distributed systems using self-stabilization algorithms, and further extend these algorithms to solve the similar problems in P2P systems, wireless ad-hoc networks, and social networks.  We also studied the energy efficiency problem in cloud systems and proposed different algorithms to reduce the energy consumption of a cloud system while improving the system performance.

 
We have redesigned G-SESAME web services with more tools and improved algorithms. Five different methods of measuring the semantic similarity of GO terms have been integrated into the web services. Now people can choose their desired algorithm to measure the semantic similarity of GO terms, and to measure the functional similarity of genes. A tool to measure the functional similarity of proteins found in UniProt (http://www.ebi.ac.uk/uniprot/) is also published in G-SESAME website. A tool to measure the functional similarity of pathways found in in Reactome (http://reactome.org/) is also available in the website. We also implemented a tool to measure the semantic similarity of terms in pathway ontology found in biological ontology portal (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/). A forum is implemented to allow people to exchange related research information.

Our research findings have been disseminated through conference presentations and journal publications. More than 30 papers were published in various conference proceedings and journals and 10 more papers are currently under review or in preparation. In addition to improving our G-SESAME website (http://bioinformatics.clemson.edu/G-SESAME) with a new design and the integration of our new algorithms and research results, we have also published an ontology graph based search engine, G-Bean (http://bioinformatics.clemson.edu/G-Bean), to provide an efficient web tool to search biomedical articles from the MEDLINE database. Our G-SESAME web services have been used by researchers from 250 institutions all over the world. Our G-Bean search engine has been accessed by people from 90 countries.


Nine PhD students, including one minority student and two female students, and ten MS students participated in different parts of this project. Six of these nine PhD students have graduated, including one female student and one minority student. Six undergraduate students, including two female and two minority students, were trained in this project through REU programs. Research results from this project have been discussed in various graduate courses, such as Data Mining, Machine Learning, and Information Retrieval, in the School of Computing at Clemson University. Term projects derived from this project have been used in these courses as well.
